instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.SYS_DETECT_L: What is SYS_DETECT_L? For detection of the battery.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no battery
threads.message: water damaged macbook, without a battery, works 100%, attach battery, battery % shows up and seams to be charging. randomly will shut down. if i measure the power pins on the battery while plugged in, the voltage jumps all over, leading me to believe there is a short but nothing seams to be shorted. i removed <TRANSISTOR>Q7155</TRANSISTOR> and the battery voltage was stable, replaced with spare, and same problem. i have tried 3 different batteries. anyone have a similar issue or have some way to force what ever is shorting out to fail so i can find it?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no battery
threads.message: Checked resistance between pins 17/18, 27/28 of the <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP>? It does shut down with AC and battery connected too?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no battery
threads.message: ac + battery = crash. ac only no crash. battery only wont power.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no battery
threads.message: and on pin 17/18 im getting almost 0 resistance, on 27/28 im getting about 20 resistance

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no battery
threads.message: That seems fine. Is PP3V42 present when on battery only? PPBUS voltage too?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no battery
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> yes 3.41v  <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is all over the place, from 12v down to 1 then back up

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no battery
threads.message: So PPBUS on battery alone is going up and down? <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> is also suspect.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no battery
threads.message: yeah only on battery, on ac its fine

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no battery
threads.message: I don't see how the battery voltage can be pulled low unless there is some serious current dragging it down. Also check if <SIGNAL>SYS_DETECT_L</SIGNAL>  is staying low. Where was the liquid damage?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no battery
threads.message: <SIGNAL>SYS_DETECT_L</SIGNAL> is jumping between 1.7v to 2.7

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no battery
threads.message: <SIGNAL>SYS_DETECT_L</SIGNAL> should be low. Is the 10K pull down resistor ok? Is there corrosion in the battery connector that is messing with it? You could short out the 10K pull down and see if PPBUS stabilizes.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no battery
threads.message: the 10k resistor is measuring 10k ohm  and yes its pin 2 is tied to ground so it should be pulling down

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no battery
threads.message: I asked to short out the resistor to make sure corrosion under the battery connector can not cause a pull-up effect. Short the resistor and see of PPBUS stabilizes.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no battery
threads.message: yes ppbus stablized and so did the power pins, tho it won turn on. im guesing bc its shorted to ground battery wont work

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no battery
threads.message: sorry inm not to sure what to do from there, the 10k resistor is good, so why is it not pulling down. jumping pin 1 to ground workes to stabalize battery power,

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no battery
threads.message: I suspect corrosion under the battery connector or just another dead battery.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no battery
threads.message: i ultrasonic-ed it once already, should i give it another go? and this happens with all batteries i put in, so it cant be a bad battery

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no battery
threads.message: Ultrasonic does not clean under connector/chips!!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no battery
threads.message: ok so i guess im gonna ask a stupid question. how does one remove corrosion under the plastic battery connector if ultrasonic does not remove corrosion.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no battery
threads.message: You remove it....
